FOIL method

text.text: Expand \( (\sqrt{x+29} + 1)^2 \) using the FOIL method. What is the result?

texts.feedback:
Congratulations! That is correct!

Here's how we solved it:

To expand \( (\sqrt{x+29} + 1)^2 \) using the FOIL method, first, expand the expression to:

 \( (\sqrt{x+29} + 1)*(\sqrt{x+29} + 1) \)

 

FOIL reminds us to multiply First Outer Inner Last terms and add them together.

First: \( \sqrt{x+29}*\sqrt{x+29} = (x+29)\)

Outer: \( \sqrt{x+29}*1= \sqrt{x+29}\)

Inner: \( 1*\sqrt{x+29}= \sqrt{x+29}\)

Last: \(1*1=1\)

Adding all terms, gives us \( x+2\sqrt{x+29}+30  \)

texts.feedback:
Step 1: Recall the range of a function
Remember that the range of a function is all of its possible output values. For an upward-opening parabola, the outputs range from the vertex all the way to infinity. For a downward-opening parabola, the outputs range from the vertex all the way down to negative infinity.
Step 2: Find the vertex
First find the axis of symmetry, which is located at \( x = \frac{-b}{2a} = \frac{-12}{2(-3)} = 2\). The \(y\)-value at the vertex is obtained by evaluating the function at \( x = 2 \): \( f(2) = -3(2)^2 +12(2) - 5 = -12+24-5 = 7\). The vertex is at \( (2, 7) \).
Step 4: Up or down? Find the range
The parabola opens downward because the coefficient of the \( x^2 \) term is negative. That means that the \( y \) value of \( 7 \) at the vertex will be the maximum of the range. Everything else is below it.

texts.feedback:
That's right! The value \( x = 2 \) is an extraneous solution for the equation \( \frac{x+2}{x-2} = \frac{20}{x^2+x-6} \).

Here's how we found it:

First note that \( x = 2 \) causes division by zero on the left side and \( x = 2 \) and \( x = -3 \) cause division by zero on the right side.

Solve the problem:

\( \frac{x+2}{x-2} = \frac{20}{x^2+x-6} \)

\(  \frac{x+2}{x-2} = \frac{20}{(x-2)(x+3)} \)

\(  x+2 = \frac{20}{x+3} \)

\( (x+2)(x+3) = 20 \)

\( x^2 + 5x + 6 = 20 \)

\( x^2 + 5x - 14 = 0 \)

\( (x + 7)(x - 2) = 0 \)

\( x = -7, 2 \)

The solution is \( x = -7 \) and \( x = 2 \) is extraneous.

texts.feedback:
Step 1: Quadratic functions are parabolas
Remember that quadratic functions like \( y = ax^2 + bx + c \) look like parabolas when they are graphed.
Step 2: Features of a parabola
A parabola comes in two basic forms. It either opens upward or opens downward. If the parabola opens up, it has one minimum, which is at its vertex. If it opens downward, it has one maximum, also at its vertex. The axis of symmetry is an imaginary vertical line that runs right through the vertex.

texts.feedback:
The graph shows the function \( f(x) = x^3 - 4x^2 \).

There are several important features to know from the graph:

  • Double root at \( x = 0 \)
  • Root at \( x = 4 \)
  • \( f(x) \to +\infty \) as \( x \to \infty \)
  • \( f(x) \to -\infty \) as \( x \to -\infty \)

The first two observations mean that \( f(x) = x^2 (x-4) g(x) \) for some polynomial \( g(x) \).

The last two observations imply that the polynomial has an odd order with a positive coefficient.

The function \( f(x) = x^3 - 4x^2 \) is the only option matching these criteria.

texts.feedback:
The function \( f(x) = \frac{x-2}{x^2-4x-12} \) has the attributes:

  • vertical asymptote at \( x = -2 \)
  • vertical asymptote at \( x = 6 \)
  • \(x\)-intercept at \( (2,0) \)

There are many (actually, infinitely many) functions that share these properties, but the simplest one can be designed as follows:

Vertical asymptotes exist at \( x \)-values that lead to division by zero in the function.

An \( x \)-intercept is the value of \( x \) at which the function is zero.

Putting these together, we could propose the function \( f(x) = \frac{x-2}{(x+2)(x-6)} \). If you expand the denominator, you get \( f(x) = \frac{x-2}{x^2-4x-12} \).

Target: Evaluate the product of two matrices

text.text: Let \( A = \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 3 & -1 \\ 2 & 0 & 4 \end{bmatrix} \) and \( B = \begin{bmatrix} 3 & 0 \\ -1 & 1 \\ 0 & 4 \end{bmatrix} \). What is the product \( AB \)?

texts.feedback:
Step 1: Determine product matrix order
\( A \) is \( 2 \times 3 \) and \( B \) is \( 3 \times 2 \); therefore \( AB \) will be \( 2 \times 2 \)
Step 2: Calculate the elements
\( AB = \begin{bmatrix} c_{11} & c_{12} \\ c_{21} & c_{22} \end{bmatrix} \)
\( c_{11} = \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 3 & -1 \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} 3 \\ -1 \\ 0 \end{bmatrix} = 1(3) + 3(-1) + -1(0) = 0 \)
\( c_{12} = \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 3 & -1 \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} 0 \\ 1 \\ 4 \end{bmatrix} = 1(0) + 3(1) + -1(4) = -1 \)
\( c_{21} = \begin{bmatrix} 2 & 0 & 4 \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} 3 \\ -1 \\ 0 \end{bmatrix} = 2(3) + 0(-1) + 4(0) = 6 \)
\( c_{22} = \begin{bmatrix} 2 & 0 & 4  \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} 0 \\ 1 \\ 4  \end{bmatrix} = 2(0) + 0(1) + 4(4) =16 \)
Step 3: Put it together
\( AB = \begin{bmatrix} 0 & -1 \\ 6 & 16 \end{bmatrix} \)

texts.feedback:
The vertex of the parabola given by \( f(x) = -3x^2 + 12x -5 \) is located at \( (2, 7) \). 

Here's how we did it:

The vertex of a parabola lies on the axis of symmetry, which is given by the line \( x = \frac{-b}{2a} \) for equations of the form \( f(x) = ax^2 + bx + c \). 

In this case, \( a = -3 \) and \( b = 12 \). Therefore, the axis of symmetry is \( x = \frac{-12}{2(-3)} = 2 \).

To find the \( y \)-coordinate of the vertex, we substitute \( x = 2 \) into the equation for the parabola: \( f(2) = -3(2)^2 + 12(2) - 5 = 7 \).

The vertex is located at \( (2, 7) \).

text.text:
The function \( f(x) \) is shown in the graph below.

Which of the following graphs shows the function \( f^{-1} (x) \)?

texts.feedback:
Step 1: Recall what is the inverse
The inverse \( f^{-1} \) is the function that converts \( f\)'s outputs into its inputs. Normally, we input \( x \) and get \( y = f(x) \). You can think of the inverse as a function where you put in \( y \) and get back \( x = f^{-1}(y) \).
Step 2: Graphical representation
All of the \( x \) and \( y \) values of the points on the graph of \( f \) are switched in the graph of \( f^{-1} \). This is equivalent to flipping the graph over the line \( y=x \) that runs diagonally from the lower left to upper right on our axes.
Step 3: Sketch \( y = x \)
Sketch the line \( y = x \) lightly in pencil.
Step 4: Mirror the graph
Mirror the graph of \( f(x) \) onto the other side of the line. That is the inverse function \( f^{-1} \)

Solving \( \frac{1}{A} = \frac{1}{B} + \frac{1}{C} \) for \( A \) yields the solution \( A = \frac{BC}{B+C} \).

Let's see how we did it:

\( \frac{1}{A} = \frac{1}{B} + \frac{1}{C} \)

\( \frac{1}{A} = \frac{C}{BC} + \frac{B}{BC} \)

\( \frac{1}{A} = \frac{B+C}{BC} \)

\( BC = (B+C)A \)

\( \frac{BC}{B+C} = A \)

displayName.text: Maximum of a Parabola

text.text: Jill makes and sells homemade cakes. Her daily profit is represented by the function \(P(x) = -x^2 + 10x + 34\), where \(P(x)\) is her daily profit (in dollars) and \(x\) is the number of cakes she sold. What is the maximum daily profit Jill can earn?

texts.feedback:
Jill can earn a maximum of $59 of profit in one day.

Here's how we solved it:

\(P(x) = -x^2 + 10x + 34\) is a parabola that opens down because of the negative coefficient on \(x^2\)

The maximum of a downward opening parabola is at its vertex, which lies on the axis of symmetry

The axis of symmetry is the line \(x = \frac{-b}{2a} = 5\)

\(P(5) = -(5)^2 + 10(5) + 34 = 59\)

Here's how we solved it:

\(y=x^2-2x-24\) is an upward-opening parabola

For an upward-opening parabola, \(y<0\) between the two \(x\)-intercepts (if they exist)

Find the \(x\) intercepts: \(x = \frac{-b \pm \sqrt{b^2-4ac}}{2a} = \frac{-(-2) \pm \sqrt{(2)^2-4(1)(-24)}}{2(1)} = \frac{2 \pm \sqrt{100}}{2} = 1 \pm 5 = -4, 6 \) 

The solution is then \( -4 < x < 6 \). This is written in interval notation as \( (-4, 6) \).

displayName.text: Radical Eqns - Extraneous Soln

text.text:
Which of the following is an extraneous solution for the equation below?

\( \sqrt{x+29} + 1 = x\)

texts.feedback:
Congratulations! That is correct!

Here's how we solved it. Compare our solution method to your own. 

\(\sqrt{x+29} = x-1 \) Isolate the radical.
\( (\sqrt{x+29})^2 = (x-1)^2 \) Raise both sides of the equation to an exponent of 2.
\( x+29 = x^2-2x+1 \) Evaluate each side, FOILing the right side.
\( 0 = x^2-3x-28 \) Group like terms.
\( 0 = (x-7)(x+4) \) Factor the polynomial. 
\( x = 7, -4 \) These are possible solutions for \(x\).


Now we have to determine whether or not any of these solutions are extraneous. We can do this by substituting back into the original equation: \( \sqrt{x+29} + 1 = x\)

Let's check \(x = 7\).

\( \sqrt{7+29} + 1 = 7\) Substitute 7 in for x.
\( \sqrt{36} + 1 = 7 \) \( \sqrt{36} = 6 \)
\( 7 = 7 \) 7 checks out as a valid solution.


Let's check \(x = -4\).

\( \sqrt{-4+29} + 1 = -4\) Substitute -4 in for x.
\( \sqrt{25} + 1 = -4 \) \( \sqrt{25} = 5 \)
\( 6 = -4 \) This is not true. \(x = -4\) is an extraneous solution.

displayName.text: Target: Radical Eqns - Extraneous Soln

texts.feedback:
Congratulations! That is correct!

Here's how we solved it. Compare our solution method to your own. 

\(\sqrt{x+6} = x-6 \) Isolate the radical.
\( (\sqrt{x+6})^2 = (x-6)^2 \) Raise both sides of the equation to an exponent of 2.
\( x+6 = x^2-12x+36 \) Evaluate each side, FOILing the right side.
\( 0 = x^2-13x+30 \) Group like terms.
\( 0 = (x-3)(x-10) \) Factor the polynomial. 
\( x = 3, 10 \) These are possible solutions for \(x\).


Now we have to determine whether or not any of these solutions are extraneous. We can do this by substituting back into the original equation: \( \sqrt{x+6} + 6 = x\)

Check \(x = 3\).

\( \sqrt{3+6} + 6 = 3\) Substitute 3 in for x.
\( \sqrt{9} + 6 = 3 \) \( \sqrt{9} = 3 \)
\( 9 = 3 \) This is not true. \(x = 3\) is an extraneous solution.


Check \(x = 10\). 

\( \sqrt{10+6} + 6 = 10\) Substitute 10 in for x.
\( \sqrt{16} + 6 = 10 \) \( \sqrt{16} = 4 \)
\( 10 = 10 \) x=10 checks out as a valid solution.

Recall that exponentiation is the inverse of taking the log. If we raise both sides to an exponent with base 25, we can eliminate the log from the equation. Here's how we did it:

displayName.text: Target: Solve a logarithmic equation with extraneous solution(s)

text.text: Solve the logarithmic equation \( \ln(5x-1) = \ln(6) - \ln(x-6) \) for \( x \).

texts.feedback:
The solution to the equation \( \ln(5x-1) = \ln(6) - \ln(x-6) \) is \( x = \frac{31}{5} \). (Note that \( x = 0 \) is an extraneous solution because it is outside the domain of the functions.)

Here's how we solved it:

\( \ln(5x-1) = \ln(6) - \ln(x-6) = \ln \frac{6}{x-6} \)

\( 5x - 1 = \frac{6}{x-6} \)

\( (5x-1)(x-6) = 6 \)

\( 5x^2 - 31x + 6 = 6 \)

\( 5x^2 -31x = 0 \)

\( x(5x-31) = 0 \)

\( x = 0 \) or \( x = \frac{31}{5} \)

Note that \( x = 0 \) is not in the domain of \( \ln (5x-1) \) nor is it in the domain of \( \ln(x-6) \), so it is an extraneous solution.

The answer is  \( x = \frac{31}{5} \).

text.text: Solve the equation \( x^2 + 4x + 40 = 0 \) to obtain exact solutions.

texts.feedback:
The quadratic equation \( x^2 + 4x + 40 = 0 \) has two solutions \( -2 \pm 6i \).

We use the quadratic formula to find the roots of the equation, which is written generally \( ax^2 + bx + c = 0 \). 

Here we have \( a = 1 \), \( b = 4 \), and \( c = 40 \), just by inspection.

\( x = \frac{ -b \pm \sqrt{b^2 - 4ac}}{2a} = \frac{-(4) \pm \sqrt{(4)^2 - 4(1)(40)}}{2(1)} = \frac{-4 \pm \sqrt{-144}}{2} = \frac{ -4 \pm 12i}{2} = -2 \pm 6i \)

Target: Solve an exponential equation word problem

text.text: There are currently 68 million cars in France, and that number is increasing exponentially at a rate of 7.2% annually. How many years will it take until France has 77 million cars? (Round your answer to three decimal places.)

texts.feedback:
At an annual rate of 7.2%, the number of cars in France will grow from 68 million to 77 million in 1.788 years.

To solve this problem, we use the formula for compounding interest where the time \( t \) is unknown. Recall that the formula is \( A = P ( 1 + rn)^{nt} \) where \( A \) is the value after \( P \) undergoes growth at a rate of \( r \) (represented as a decimal), compounded \( n \) times per year, for a total of \( t \) years. 

In this problem, we want to determine how many years \( t \) it will take for \( P = 68,000,000 \) cars to grow to \( A = 77,000,000 \) cars at an annual growth rate of \( r = 0.072 \). (In this case there is no compounding, so \( n = 1 \).) Therefore, we must solve the exponential equation:

\( 78000000 = 66000000(1+0.072)^t \) 

Here's how we do it:

\( \frac{78}{66} = 1.072^t \)

\( \ln \frac{78}{66} = t \ln 1.072 \)

\( t = \frac{ \ln \frac{78}{66} }{ \ln 1.072 } = 1.788 \)

displayName.text: Target: Solve an exponential equation word problem

texts.feedback:
The equation \( \frac{3x}{x-3} - \frac{4}{x} = \frac{12}{x^2-3x} \) has solution \( x = \frac{4}{3} \) and extraneous solution \( x = 0 \).

Here's how we did it:

First note that the equation is only valid for \( x \neq 3 \) and \( x \neq 0 \) based on solving \( d(x) = 0 \) for each of the denominators \( d \).

\( \frac{3x}{x-3} - \frac{4}{x} = \frac{12}{x^2-3x} \)

\( \frac{3x^2}{x(x-3)} - \frac{4(x-3)}{x(x-3)} = \frac{12}{x^2-3x} \)

\( \frac{3x^2}{x^2-3x} - \frac{4(x-3)}{x^2-3x} = \frac{12}{x^2-3x} \)

\( 3x^2 - 4(x-3) = 12 \)

\( 3x^2 - 4x + 12 = 12 \)

\( 3x^2 -4x = 0 \)

\( x(x-\frac{4}{3}) = 0 \)

This tells us that \(x = 0 \) and \( x = \frac{4}{3} \) solve the equation. BUT WAIT! Because we analyzed the domain at the beginning, we know \( x = 0 \) is extraneous, and \( x = \frac{4}{3} \) is the solution.

text.text:
Solve to obtain the exact solutions.

\(3x^3+x^2-48x-16=0\)

texts.feedback:
This is how we solved it. Work through each step of the process to make sure you understand it.

Step 1: Use the Rational Roots Test to identify possible solutions. 

  Factors \((\pm)\)
Constant Term: -16  1, 2, 4, 8, 16
Leading coefficient: 3  1, 3

Possible solutions: \(\frac{factors of constant term}{factors of leading coefficient}\): \( \pm 1, \pm \frac{1}{3}, \pm 2, \pm \frac{2}{3}, \pm 4, \pm \frac{4}{3}, \pm 8, \pm \frac{8}{3}, \pm 16, \pm \frac{16}{3}\)

Step 2: Check possible solutions to see if any are real solutions.

Let's try x=4.

\(3x^3+x^2-48x-16=0\)

\(3*(4^3)+(4^2)-(48*4)-16=0\)

192 + 16 - 192 -16 = 0 (insert checkmark here)

x=4 is one solution to the polynomial \(3x^3+x^2-48x-16=0\)

Step 3: Use division to find lower order polynomial.

If x = 4 is a solution, we know that (x-4) is a linear factor of \(3x^3+x^2-48x-16=0\). You can use long division or synthetic division to find the lower order polynomial.

We're going to use synthetic division.

This gives a quadratic equation \(3x^2 + 13x + 4 = 0\)

Step 4: Solve the quadratic equation to find the remaining solutions.

\(3x^2 + 13x + 4 = 0\)

This equation could be factored or solved using the quadratic formula.

\((3x + 1)(x+4) = 0\)

\(x=-\frac{1}{3}, -4\) are two additional solutions.

In summary, the solutions to the polynomial \(3x^3+x^2-48x-16=0\) are \( x = -4, \frac{-1}{3}, 4\).

displayName.text: Target: Solve polynomial for exact solution

texts.feedback:
The equation \( 5x^2 -7x = 1 \) has exact solutions \( x = \frac {7 \pm \sqrt{69}}{10} \).

We solved for x using the quadratic formula: \( x = \frac{-b \pm \sqrt{b^2 - 4ac}}{2a}\).

To apply the quadratic formula, we first need to write the equation in \( ax^2 + bx + c = 0 \) form:

 \( 5x^2 -7x = 1\)

 \(5x^2 -7x - 1 = 1 - 1\)

\(5x^2 -7x - 1 = 0\)

Now that the equation is in the form \( ax^2 + bx + c = 0 \), we see that a = 5, b = -7, and c = -1.

Substituting into the quadratic formula, gives us the exact solutions:

\( x = \frac{-b \pm \sqrt{b^2 - 4ac}}{2a} = \frac{ -(-7) \pm \sqrt{(-7)^2-4(5)(-1)}}{2(5)} = \frac{ 7 \pm \sqrt{49+20}}{2(5)} = \frac{ 7 \pm \sqrt{69}}{10} \)

texts.feedback:
The equation \( 4x^2 -12x - 7 = 0 \) has exact solutions \( x = -\frac{1}{2} \) and \( x = \frac{7}{2} \).

We obtained the roots of the function using the quadratic formula: \( x = \frac{-b \pm \sqrt{b^2 - 4ac}}{2a}\)

The equation is already in the standard form of \(ax^2 + bx + c = 0\), where a = 4, b = -12, and c = -7. 

\( x = \frac{-b \pm \sqrt{b^2 - 4ac}}{2a} = \frac{ -(-12) \pm \sqrt{(-12)^2-4(4)(-7)}}{2(4)} = \frac{ 12 \pm \sqrt{256}}{8} = \frac{-1}{2}, \frac{7}{2} \)

text.text: Solve the equation \( 4x^2 -12x - 7 = 0 \) to find exact solutions.

texts.feedback:
Using the intermediate value theorem we find that \( f(x) = 6x^4 + 2x^3 -2x -7 \) has a real zero between \( -2 \) and \( -1 \).

The intermediate value theorem says that if \( f(a) \) and \( f(b) \) have opposite sign, then there must be at least one real zero of \( f(x) \) between \( a \) and \( b \).

In this case, \( f(-2) = 77 \) and \( f(-1) = -1 \). These are opposite signs, so there must \( f \) must have a real zero between \( -2 \) and \( -1 \).

texts.feedback:
Step 1: Recall extraneous solutions
When we solve problems algebraically, we sometimes perform operations that exclude values from being solutions. For example, we know that multiplying both sides of any equation by 0 will make the equality true: \( 0 = 0 \) after all!
Step 2: What are the possible extraneous solutions here?
If we multiplied the equation by \( x-2 \) and \( x+3 \), then we need to remember that \( x=2 \) and \( x = -3 \) would be extraneous solutions if they appear as possible solutions at the end of the process. Those values would negate earlier steps because \( 0 = 0 \) always!

displayName.text: Understand that extraneous solutions should not be stated as solutions since they are not part of the domain

texts.feedback:
Step 1: Recall the definition of the domain of a function
The domain of a function is all of the valid inputs to the function. In other words, it is all of the values \( x \) for which there is a corresponding output \( y = f(x) \).

displayName.text: Understand that the domain of a function is all possible inputs

choices.name: Choice 2

texts.feedback:
Step 1: Recall the definition of the range
The range of a function is defined to be all of the possible outputs of a function. It is related to the domain of a function because if you evaluate the function at every value in the domain, you will get every value in the range as outputs.

displayName.text: Understand that vertical asymptotes occur where the denominator of a function is zero

text.text: What equation would you solve to find the location of the vertical asymptote(s) of the function \( f(x) = \frac{g(x)}{h(x)} \)?

texts.feedback:
Step 1: Recall what is a vertical asymptote
A vertical asymptote is a vertical line (e.g., \( x = c \) for constant \( c \)) corresponding to an \(x \) value where a function blows up to \( +\infty \) or blows "down" to \( -\infty \)
Step 2: Zero-denominator vertical asymptotes
One common generator of a vertical asymptote occurs when the denominator of a fraction vanishes to 0. (There are other ways, including when the argument of a logarithm goes to 0.)
Step 3: Final answer
For \( f(x) = \frac{g(x)}{h(x)} \), vertical asymptotes occur where \( h(x) = 0 \)

displayName.text: Understand that vertical asymptotes occur where the denominator of a function is zero

texts.feedback:
Step 1: Recall the definition of the \( x \)-intercept
An \( x \)-intercept exists where the function crosses the \( x \)-axis.
Step 2: Write the equation for the \( x \)-axis
The \( x \)-axis is the line where all points have a \( y \)-value of 0. The \(x \)-axis is the line \( y = 0 \).
Step 3: Solve for when the function and \( x \)-axis intersect
\( y = f(x) \) intersects \( y = 0 \) when \( f(x) = 0 \), by substitution for \(y\).

displayName.text: Understand that x-intercepts occur where f(x)=0
Understand that x-intercepts occur where f(x)=0

text.text: Which of the following equations or expressions corresponds to the \( x \)-intercept of a function?

texts.feedback:
Step 1: Find the roots
The roots occur where the function crosses the \( x \)-axis.
Step 2: Analyze the local behavior around each root
If the function behaves like a quadratic near the root, i.e., it looks like \( f(x) = \pm (x-r)^2 \) where \( r \) is the root, then that is a double root.

displayName.text: Understand the behavior of a double root near the x-axis
Understand the behavior of a double root near the x-axis

text.text:
Most real roots of polynomials just pass right through the \( x \)-axis. Double roots are special. They do not pass through the axis from positive to negative (or negative to positive) \( y \)-values. Their behavior near the root is more like that of a quadratic.

text.text: Which of the following intervals contains all of the values between 3 and 7 inclusive?

texts.feedback:
Step 1: Recall the meaning of an inclusive interval
Inclusive intervals/ranges include the endpoints.
Step 2: Interval notation for inclusive interval
When an endpoint is included in the interval, we use the bracket \( [ \) or \( ] \). (If the endpoint is not included it is an "open" interval, and we use parenthesis \( ( \) or \( ) \).

displayName.text: Understand the difference between open and closed interval

texts.feedback:
The function \( f(x) = \frac{1}{3}x^2 - \frac{2}{3}x - \frac{8}{3} \) has roots at \(x = -2 \) and \( x = 4 \) and vertex at \( (1, -3 ) \).

Here's how we found the right function:

With roots at \( x = -2 \) and \( x = 4 \), we know that \( f(x) = a (x+2)(x-4)  = a(x^2 - 2x - 8) \) for some real number \( a \).

We can find \( a \) by setting the vertex. We know \( f(1) = -9a = -3 \) so \( a = -\frac{1}{3} \). 

Multiply through by \( a =\frac{-1}{3} \) to get \( f(x) = \frac{1}{3}x^2 - \frac{2}{3}x - \frac{8}{3} \).

displayName.text: Understand the end behavior of a cubic function

text.text: Which of the following diagrams accurately represents the end behavior of a cubic polynomial function with positive coefficient on the \( x^3 \) term?

texts.feedback:
Step 1: Recall the algebraic definition of a cubic function
A cubic function has the form \( y = ax^3 + bx^2 + cx + d \).
Step 2: Study the behavior for very large (positive and negative) values of \(x\)
At very large (positive or negative) values of \( x \), the cubic term dominates the behavior in the cubic function. At the far ends, we can approximate \( y \approx ax^3 \). If \( a > 0 \), then the graph will go down and to the left (for large negative values) and up and to the right (for large positive values). If \( a < 0 \), it switches: down and to the right (for large positive values) and up and to the left (for negative values).

displayName.text: Understand the end behavior of a cubic function
Understands that \( i = \sqrt{-1} \)

text.text: Write the first four terms of the sequence \( i^k \) where \( k = 0, 1, 2, 3 \), simplifying as much as possible.

texts.feedback:
Step 1: Recall the definition of \( i \)
\( i = \sqrt{-1} \)
Step 2: Perform the exponentiation
\( i^0 = 1 \), by definition
\( i^1 = i \)
\( i^2 = \sqrt{-1}\cdot \sqrt{-1} = -1 \)
\( i^3 = i^2 \cdot i = -1 \cdot i = -i \)

displayName.text: Understands that \( i = \sqrt{-1} \)

text.text: Rewrite the expression \( -\log_b (3) \) into an equivalent expression without using a negative sign.

texts.feedback:
Step 1: Recall the quadratic formula
The quadratic formula \( x = \frac{-b \pm \sqrt{b^2 - 4ac}}{2a}\) tells us the roots of a quadratic function of the form \( y = ax^2 + bx + c \).
Step 2: Identify the constants a, b, and c
For the equation \( y = x^2 + 12x + 30 \), we see that a = 1, b = 12, and c = 30.
Step 3: Substitute and solve
\( x = \frac{-b \pm \sqrt{b^2 - 4ac}}{2a} \)
\( = \frac{ -(12) \pm \sqrt{(12)^2-4(1)(30)}}{2} \)
\(= \frac{ -12 \pm \sqrt{24}}{2} \)
\(= \frac{ -12 \pm 2\sqrt{6}}{2} \)
\(= -6\pm \sqrt{6} \)

Step 1: Recall the definition of an ordered pair
An ordered pair represents the coordinates of a point on a graph
Step 2: Write an ordered pair as \( (x, y) \)
The \(x\) value measures distance to the right and \(y\) value measures distance up from the origin. The ordered pair is always written in the order with \(x\) first.

displayName.text: Write the equation for a vertical asymptote

text.text: What is the equation for the vertical line passing through \( (3,0) \)?

texts.feedback:
Step 1: Recall the equation for a vertical line
Vertical lines have an equation of the form \( x = c \) for some constant \(c\). All of the points on a vertical line share the same \( x \) value.
Step 2: Determine the constant
A vertical line running through \( (3,0) \) has an \( x \) value of \( 3 \); therefore all of its \( x \) values must be \( 3 \), so \( x = 3 \) is the equation of the line.
